abstract: The United Kingdom's COVID-19 epidemic during early 2020 was one of world's largest and was unusually well represented by virus genomic sampling. We determined the fine-scale genetic lineage structure of this epidemic through analysis of 50,887 severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) genomes, including 26,181 from the UK sampled throughout the country's first wave of infection. Using large-scale phylogenetic analyses combined with epidemiological and travel data, we quantified the size, spatiotemporal origins, and persistence of genetically distinct UK transmission lineages. Rapid fluctuations in virus importation rates resulted in >1000 lineages; those introduced prior to national lockdown tended to be larger and more dispersed. Lineage importation and regional lineage diversity declined after lockdown, whereas lineage elimination was size-dependent. We discuss the implications of our genetic perspective on transmission dynamics for COVID-19 epidemiology and control.

Cancer cells enter a reversible drug-tolerant persister (DTP) state to evade death from chemotherapy and targeted agents. It is increasingly appreciated that DTPs are important drivers of therapy failure and tumor relapse. We combined cellular barcoding and mathematical modeling in patient-derived colorectal cancer models to identify and characterize DTPs in response to chemotherapy. Barcode analysis revealed no loss of clonal complexity of tumors that entered the DTP state and recurred following treatment cessation. Our data fit a mathematical model where all cancer cells, and not a small subpopulation, possess an equipotent capacity to become DTPs. Mechanistically, we determined that DTPs display remarkable transcriptional and functional similarities to diapause, a reversible state of suspended embryonic development triggered by unfavorable environmental conditions. Our study provides insight into how cancer cells use a developmentally conserved mechanism to drive the DTP state, pointing to novel therapeutic opportunities to target DTPs.

2021 marks the 30th anniversary of the revelation that cyclosporin A and FK506 act in a way previously not seen—as “molecular glues” that induce neo-protein–protein associations. As a torrent of new molecular-glue probes and medicines are fueling interest in this field, I explore the arc of this story. 2021 marks the 30th anniversary of the revelation that cyclosporin A and FK506 act in a way previously not seen—as “molecular glues” that induce neo-protein–protein associations. As a torrent of new molecular-glue probes and medicines are fueling interest in this field, I explore the arc of this story. Long before anyone knew that cyclosporin A (CsA; sandimmune) was a molecular glue, or that by 2018 it would be prescribed over 2 million times per year, a biologist working for the Swiss pharmaceutical company Sandoz picked up a soil sample while vacationing with his wife in Norway in 1971. It was routine for employees to take such collections as part of a screening program aimed at finding microorganisms harboring antifungal antibiotics, but it was the immunosuppressive activity of CsA that captured the attention of Sandoz. By 1979, CsA was being used in patients to prevent organ transplant rejections and was approved by the FDA in 1983. Meanwhile in 1983, the Japanese pharmaceutical company Fujisawa was busy developing a discovery program that actually was looking for immunosuppressants by screening for novel bioactive microbial products. This was how, in 1987, they discovered the storied FK506 (tacrolimus), a novel 23-membered macrolide that had similar activity to CsA but was more potent and appeared to provide better prognostic outcomes in organ-transplant patients (Schreiber and Crabtree, 1992Schreiber S.L. Crabtree G.R. The mechanism of action of cyclosporin A and FK506.Immunol. Today. 1992; 13: 136-142Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1904) Google Scholar). What followed was a 4-year race to uncover the molecular mechanisms of CsA and FK506’s activities in hopes of creating even better analogs, and it culminated in a new field of molecular glues. But how did we get to this point? And how have the past 30 years delivered on the promise of molecular glues? Molecular glues are the proverbial water coolers of biology. It was the mid-80s at Yale, and because I was waiting for Bill Prusoff, I bumped into Bob Handschumacher. Bob told me about CsA targeting cyclophilin for immunosuppression. From his work, we had learned that cyclophilin was a small (18 kD) and abundant protein with an odd enzymatic activity—it catalyzes the interconversion of cis- and trans-rotamers of proline residues in proteins. As it turned out, CsA inhibits this “peptidyl–prolyl isomerase” activity. But there was no obvious connection between cyclophilin and immunosuppression. Prolyl isomerization is facile, occurring on the time frame of milliseconds to seconds, so from a chemist’s perspective it was hard to imagine that catalyzing or inhibiting this process would have cellular significance. So, how could we connect the dots from this seemingly inconsequential function to the inhibition of T cell receptor (TCR)-mediated signaling by CsA? My curiosity was piqued. I wondered whether there might be other compounds with similar properties. It was my custom then to search for natural products in newly reported patent applications, which led to the recognition of FK506 in 1986 as an intriguing candidate. The pharmaceutical company Fujisawa, now named Astellas, had discovered FK506 by searching for natural products that could interfere with TCR signaling. Since my insight preceded the publication of the compound, I was hopeful that I might have a jump on what I imagined would quickly become a competitive field. But the unusual structure of the macrocyclic polyketide FK506 also jogged my memory. Sure enough, I hit the jackpot searching through my index cards—the pre-Internet method scientists used to keep track of the scientific literature. In 1980 in the Canadian Journal of Chemistry, scientists at Ayerst had reported on a different but structurally related macrocyclic polyketide named rapamycin, which had been discovered as an antifungal agent. I imagined it had been discarded, since no reports were obvious to me in the interim. Now I was even more excited—maybe rapamycin, like FK506, would also have CsA-like activity. The value system of organic chemists in the 1980s placed an emphasis on being the first to synthesize newly reported natural products, especially ones with complex and novel structural features. My discussions with Handschumacher left me determined to place greater emphasis on discovering targets and uncovering mechanisms of action of FK506 and rapamycin. But instead, I succumbed to my fear of not winning the traditional race and invested considerable lab time and resources on the eventually successful “total syntheses” of both FK506 and rapamycin. But a move from Yale to Harvard in 1988 catalyzed a return to my gut instincts, and efforts on target identification were underway within the first 2 weeks of arrival at Harvard. The targets of FK506 and rapamycin were quickly discovered using affinity chromatography. Although the first target, FKBP12, had subnanomolar interactions with both compounds, other targets showed differential binding—FKBP25 showing selective binding to rapamycin. Remarkably, each of these FKBPs, like cyclophilin earlier, displayed drug-sensitive peptidyl–prolyl isomerase activity. The pendulum tilted back ever so slightly in terms of the potential relevance of this activity—now, three immunosuppressive agents target proteins having this same, odd enzymatic activity. The cyclophilins and FKBPs were christened “immunophilins” as a hedge (Schreiber, 1991Schreiber S.L. Chemistry and biology of the immunophilins and their immunosuppressive ligands.Science. 1991; 251: 283-287Crossref PubMed Scopus (1314) Google Scholar). Having been schooled in the mountain-climbing ethos of natural-product synthesis, the euphoria of discovering FKBPs was a striking contrast. It unleashed a flurry of determined activity to exploit the compounds as probes of the biology they modulate. This was reinforced when I spoke to immunology colleagues who described intracellular signal transduction as a “black box” and noted that their most powerful probes—antibodies to cell-surface receptors—fail to penetrate cellular membranes, which small molecules do reliably. My organic chemistry lab expanded into molecular and cell biology, accelerated through early collaborations with immunologists Barbara Bierer and Steven Burakoff. Together in 1990, we found the next surprise: structurally related FK506 and rapamycin disrupt two distinct pathways. FK506 disrupts TCR signaling, while rapamycin disrupts IL2-receptor signaling. To make this even more puzzling, the cyclophilin–CsA complex behaved analogously to the FK506 complex, even though it did not engage FKBP12. This strange result suggested a novel possibility: the FKBP12–FK506 and FKBP12–rapamycin complexes had distinct properties that targeted the two different pathways. If this were true, then simply binding FKBP12 would be insufficient to achieve these variable responses, but competitively binding FKBP12 should block the actions of these compounds. To test this hypothesis, the complex non-natural macrocycle 506BD (FKBP12-binding domain of FK506 and rapamycin) was designed and its multi-step synthesis was achieved. 506BD was able to eliminate potently the cellular activities of FK506 and rapamycin (but not CsA, which doesn’t bind FKBP12) (Bierer et al., 1990Bierer B.E. Somers P.K. Wandless T.J. Burakoff S.J. Schreiber S.L. Probing immunosuppressant action with a nonnatural immunophilin ligand.Science. 1990; 250: 556-559Crossref PubMed Scopus (292) Google Scholar). Merging synthetic chemistry with cell biology pointed to a “gain-of-function” model (Schreiber, 1991Schreiber S.L. Chemistry and biology of the immunophilins and their immunosuppressive ligands.Science. 1991; 251: 283-287Crossref PubMed Scopus (1314) Google Scholar) (and put an end in my lab to synthesizing natural products for the sake of winning races). “Are these modular natural products functioning as molecular glues?” could now be overheard at my lab meetings. We thought FKBP12 might be serving as something akin to a command module with the immunosuppressants acting as the docking assembly, but we hadn’t found the lunar module yet. To find it, or them, then-postdoc Jun Liu extended our affinity-chromatography studies, this time using cyclophilin–CsA, FKBP12–FK506, and FKBP12–rapamycin as baits. Cyclophilin–CsA and FKBP12–FK506 (but not FKBP12–rapamycin, a mystery for a later day) bound the protein phosphatase calcineurin (Figure 1). CsA and FK506 are molecular glues! (Liu et al., 1991Liu J. This novel mechanism also led chemists like me initially to suffer “natural-product envy” due to a belief that the simultaneous emergence of these exquisite docking assemblies was beyond the realm of our ability to design and could only result from a billion years of natural selection. In spite of this belief, or maybe because of the challenge it posed to inquisitive chemists, this alluring mechanism was expanded far beyond the natural ones, as we will see below. Mike Hall and George Levi, whose groups showed in yeast that recessive mutations of FKBP12 conferred resistance to rapamycin, supplied reassuring support for the gain-of-function model and for the notion that rapamycin would join the small club of molecular glues. We just needed to identify the lunar module. Evidence of a novel candidate gene came from the identification, by both labs, of dominant drug-resistance alleles of genes named DRR (dominant rapamycin resistant) and TOR (target of rapamycin). After using CsA and FK506 to illuminate the calcium–calcineurin–NFAT signaling pathway with Jerry Crabtree (Crabtree and Schreiber, 2009Crabtree G.R. Schreiber S.L. SnapShot: Ca2+-calcineurin-NFAT signaling.Cell. 2009; 138 (210.e1): 210Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), we returned in 1994 to unfinished business with rapamycin. David Sabatini in Sol Snyder’s lab and Eric Brown in my lab again used FKBP12–rapamycin-based affinity chromatography and purified and characterized the target of FKBP12–rapamycin as the then-unknown protein kinase mTOR, confirming that rapamycin, like CsA and FK506 before it, was also functioning as a molecular glue. David Sabatini has continued over the following 25 years to transform our knowledge of nutrient sensing via distinct mTOR complexes (mTORCs) through brilliant and illuminating experimentation (Sabatini, 2017Sabatini D.M. Twenty-five years of mTOR: Uncovering the link from nutrients to growth.Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2017; 114: 11818-11825Crossref PubMed Scopus (205) Google Scholar), and structural investigations by Jon Clardy, Hengming Ke, and Nikola Pavletich revealed atomic-resolution insights into the mechanisms used by the three natural molecular glues to induce neo-associations (Figure 1). In the 1980s, intracellular signal transduction, protein phosphatases, and protein kinases were considered undruggable targets. The first two were revealed to be myths with the discovery that the existing drug, CsA, blocks intracellular signal transduction by inhibiting a protein phosphatase. 3 years later, the protein kinases would be lifted from the undruggable list with the approval of the mTOR inhibitor sirolimus/rapamycin. More recently, proteins lacking small-molecule-binding pockets had been deemed undruggable. In 2020, our knowledge of nature’s use of FKBP12 as a command module and the polyketide biosynthetic pathway as a source of molecular glues was expanded with the discovery of the macrolide WDB002. FKBP12-WDB002 binds the virtually featureless, coiled-coil surface of the centromeric protein CEP250 (Figure 1), leaving us to wonder whether there is anything left to call undruggable. In the early 1990s, with this small but powerful set of molecular glues in our toolbox, we set out to answer questions about the role of proximity in processes such as signal transduction. The discovery of both protein scaffolds and small-molecule glues made clear the ubiquity of nature’s use of proximity to drive biology (Figure 2A). Our first inspiration came from Jerry Crabtree recognizing the concept of the immunological synapse “squeezing out everything but the TCR.” Inspired by this notion, we created the first synthetic “bifunctional” molecular glues targeting genetic fusions, which in principle enable the induction of proximity of any two proteins that can be genetically appended to FKBP12 or other small-molecule-binding modules. A “chemical inducer of proximity” (CIP) was advanced by a one-step olefin metathesis reaction marrying two FK506 molecules via a linking element in FK1012 (Figure 2Bi). From this innovation grew FK-CsA, which opened the door to using any combination of different genetic fusions. From simple molecular glues came more complex ones—bifunctional but bearing linkers (Figure 1) (Stanton et al., 2018Stanton B.Z. Chory E.J. Crabtree G.R. Chemically induced proximity in biology and medicine.Science. 2018; 359: eaao5902Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). Gene expression and repression, chromatin methylation and remodeling, organelle and membrane localization, and protein degradation can now be controlled remotely using molecular glues to induce proximal protein associations (Figures 2B–2D). In the latter case, the ingenious dTag system developed by Jay Bradner requires only a single gene fusion for targeted protein degradation of FKBP12-tagged proteins since the glue is able to recruit a native E3 ligase (Figure 2Ci.). But native proteins were next to fall prey to molecular glues coming from synthetic chemistry (Gerry and Schreiber, 2020Gerry C.J. Schreiber S.L. In 1996, graduate student Deb Hung and others discovered that a complex natural product, discodermolide, stabilizes the association of alpha and beta tubulin monomers in a manner similar to natural products such as taxol and epothilone (Figure 1). Rather than inducing neo-associations, these compounds function to stabilize the dynamic equilibrium of normally associating proteins with profound cellular consequences—here, to stabilize microtubules. Nevertheless, the underlying mechanisms of these “molecular clamps” are related to compounds inducing neo-associations. It was the discovery in 2000 that a simple synthetic compound could also induce associations of native proteins that invigorated a new direction for this field (Figures 1 and 2Div). Up to this point, we had only come across molecular glues in the form of a rapidly growing list of natural-product glues or their derivatives. They had been linked together as CIPs, mixed and matched, but the building blocks were always bestowed by nature (Figure 2B). Small-molecule screens uncovered that an “off-the-shelf” synthetic compound we named synstab-A (for synthetic stabilizer) promoted microtubule formation in vitro and in cells analogously to discodermolide and taxol (Figures 1 and 2Div) (Haggarty et al., 2000Haggarty S.J. During the years following this discovery, there has been an explosion in the discovery of molecular glues and clamps targeting native proteins. Notable examples include Jun Liu’s synthetic FKBP12-binding glues derived from a synthetic library of 506BD-like macrocyclic rapafucins that glue FKBP12 to a plethora of proteins. FKBP12–rapadocin has been identified as a lead for cancer therapeutics by targeting the adenosine transporter SLC29A1 (Figure 2Cii). It shouldn’t be a surprise that simple small molecules can act as molecular glues when you consider that post-translational modifications as small as a methyl group can induce protein–protein associations, just as a missense mutation installing a different amino acid may completely change the landscape of a protein surface and thus its interactome. Molecular glues are just a non-covalent extension of these natural modules; for example, a novel small-molecule “molecular prosthetic” was discovered that compensates for and complements a mutated tryptophan in MALT1 (Quancard et al., 2019Quancard J. These small-molecule glues induce neo-associations between distinct E3 ligase enzymes, their adaptors, and target proteins. Thalidomide and lenalidomide induce the ubiquitination of the transcription factor Ikaros via the CUL4-DDB1-RBX1-CRBN E3 ligase complex, whereas indisulam induces the ubiquitination of the splicing factor RBM39 via the CUL4-DDB1-DDA1-DCAF15 E3 ligase complex. More generally, cellular pull-down experiments of protein targets with and without compounds show changes in their targets’ interactomes with surprisingly high frequency. Far from being the exclusive domain of natural selection, synthetic compounds often function as molecular glues (Figures 2C and 2D) (Gerry and Schreiber, 2020Gerry C.J. Schreiber S.L. Unifying principles of bifunctional, proximity-inducing small molecules.Nat. Chem. Biol. 2020; 16: 369-378Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Every year since Ray Deshaies’ 2015 statement that “the gold rush is on,” we have seen an approximate doubling in publications on molecular glues (Figure 1). Among many others, David Spiegel is modulating the immune system in novel ways; Tom Wandless is making wrecking balls; Kevan Shokat is rethinking medicinal chemistry; Michelle Arkin is exploiting novel command modules; Angela Koehler is targeting transcription factors, and Pei Zhou is targeting DNA polymerases by altering subunit compositions of protein complexes; Derek Taylor and Goutham Narla are redirecting substrates of serine/threonine phosphatases, and Jidong Zhu is correcting disease-causing mutations of tyrosine phosphatases by using intramolecular molecular glues; and many labs are inducing associations between enzymes and (neo)-substrates—E3 ligases (PROTACs) (Figure 2Dii), protein kinases (PHICS), and protein phosphatases (PhoRCs). Most notably, Bradner, Craig Crews, Ray Deshaies, and now many others are advancing PROTACs, bifunctional molecular glues with linkers between individual binding cassettes, into the clinic. Like the prior FK506-to-FK1012 conversion, from simple molecular glues (thalidomide) come more complex ones with programmable activities, albeit with elaborated linkers (PROTACs) (Figure 2F). There is promise for medicines based on the concept of inducing protein associations, analogous to the dominant means of information transfer in biology in cytoplasmic signal transduction and nuclear chromatin signaling (Figure 2A). When small molecules bind proteins, they commonly change their interactomes. Assuming that proteins may have multiple binding partners in a crowded cell, small molecules have the power to change the landscape of a protein surface in ways that change the equilibrium and favor binding of a different protein. Consequences include increasing (stabilizers) or decreasing (degraders) lifetimes of their targets, changing their localizations (correctors), or activating signaling or gene expression by inducing proximity. The cooperative interactions of both protein and small-molecule elements enable drugging a wider range of targets. These features underlie the promise of molecular glues and point to a “discover a binder first, determine the consequence later” approach to precision medicine (Schreiber, 2019Schreiber S.L. A Chemical Biology View of Bioactive Small Molecules and a Binder-Based Approach to Connect Biology to Precision Medicines.Isr. J. Chem. 2019; 59: 52-59Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). We’ve learned that molecular glues are effective drugs (among others sandimmune, tacrolimus, sirolimus, thalidomide, lenalidomide, taxotere), show promise as agents to control activity of small-molecule-sensitive alleles in a form of gene therapy in humans with acute leukemia (Di Stasi et al., 2011Di Stasi A. Med. 2011; 365: 1673-1683Crossref PubMed Scopus (936) Google Scholar), and are among the most striking probes of cell circuitry, including that underlying senescence and aging. Novel approaches to degrading therapeutic targets using molecular-glue degraders and PROTACs are emerging in pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, and the drug-discovery process is being reshaped to overcome what was previously labeled as undruggable through the actions of molecular glues. New genetic tools are leading synthetic biologists to imagine the rewiring of cell circuitry by, for example, genome editing. But molecular glues allow us to imagine a future where cellular circuitry can be rewired at the level of proteins. In addition to using molecular glues for inducing neo-protein interactions and modulating challenging drug targets, novel molecular clamps can stabilize otherwise dynamic protein associations. Chemical biology is providing the means to discover molecular glues that pull proteins out of complexes and guide them to others. This offers a new modality for perturbing and understanding cell circuitry and for translating the insights gained into completely new types of therapeutics. Low-coverage whole-genome sequencing followed by imputation has been proposed as a cost-effective genotyping approach for disease and population genetics studies. However, its competitiveness against SNP arrays is undermined because current imputation methods are computationally expensive and unable to leverage large reference panels. Here, we describe a method, GLIMPSE, for phasing and imputation of low-coverage sequencing datasets from modern reference panels. We demonstrate its remarkable performance across different coverages and human populations. GLIMPSE achieves imputation of a genome for less than US$1 in computational cost, considerably outperforming other methods and improving imputation accuracy over the full allele frequency range. As a proof of concept, we show that 1× coverage enables effective gene expression association studies and outperforms dense SNP arrays in rare variant burden tests. Overall, this study illustrates the promising potential of low-coverage imputation and suggests a paradigm shift in the design of future genomic studies.

Abstract Patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) are resected human tumors engrafted into mice for preclinical studies and therapeutic testing. It has been proposed that the mouse host affects tumor evolution during PDX engraftment and propagation, affecting the accuracy of PDX modeling of human cancer. Here, we exhaustively analyze copy number alterations (CNAs) in 1,451 PDX and matched patient tumor (PT) samples from 509 PDX models. CNA inferences based on DNA sequencing and microarray data displayed substantially higher resolution and dynamic range than gene expression-based inferences, and they also showed strong CNA conservation from PTs through late-passage PDXs. CNA recurrence analysis of 130 colorectal and breast PT/PDX-early/PDX-late trios confirmed high-resolution CNA retention. We observed no significant enrichment of cancer-related genes in PDX-specific CNAs across models. Moreover, CNA differences between patient and PDX tumors were comparable to variations in multiregion samples within patients. Our study demonstrates the lack of systematic copy number evolution driven by the PDX mouse host.

Little is known about the genetic architecture of traits affecting educational attainment other than cognitive ability. We used genomic structural equation modeling and prior genome-wide association studies (GWASs) of educational attainment (n = 1,131,881) and cognitive test performance (n = 257,841) to estimate SNP associations with educational attainment variation that is independent of cognitive ability. We identified 157 genome-wide-significant loci and a polygenic architecture accounting for 57% of genetic variance in educational attainment. Noncognitive genetics were enriched in the same brain tissues and cell types as cognitive performance, but showed different associations with gray-matter brain volumes. Noncognitive genetics were further distinguished by associations with personality traits, less risky behavior and increased risk for certain psychiatric disorders. For socioeconomic success and longevity, noncognitive and cognitive-performance genetics demonstrated associations of similar magnitude. By conducting a GWAS of a phenotype that was not directly measured, we offer a view of genetic architecture of noncognitive skills influencing educational success. Genomic structural equation modeling of genome-wide association data for educational attainment and cognitive test performance is used to estimate the genetic component of variation in educational attainment that is independent of cognitive ability. The study finds that noncognitive skills account for 57% of genetic variation in educational attainment.

In cross-platform analyses of 174 metabolites, we identify 499 associations (P < 4.9 × 10-10) characterized by pleiotropy, allelic heterogeneity, large and nonlinear effects and enrichment for nonsynonymous variation. We identify a signal at GLP2R (p.Asp470Asn) shared among higher citrulline levels, body mass index, fasting glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide and type 2 diabetes, with β-arrestin signaling as the underlying mechanism. Genetically higher serine levels are shown to reduce the likelihood (by 95%) and predict development of macular telangiectasia type 2, a rare degenerative retinal disease. Integration of genomic and small molecule data across platforms enables the discovery of regulators of human metabolism and translation into clinical insights.

•Twist1+/− craniosynostosis mice exhibit elevated ICP and cognitive deficits•Suture MSCs and resorbable biomaterials can support regeneration of patent suture•Suture regeneration normalizes Twist1+/− ICP, skull shape, and cognitive function•Suture regeneration offers a biological solution for craniosynostosis patients Craniosynostosis results from premature fusion of the cranial suture(s), which contain mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) that are crucial for calvarial expansion in coordination with brain growth. Infants with craniosynostosis have skull dysmorphology, increased intracranial pressure, and complications such as neurocognitive impairment that compromise quality of life. Animal models recapitulating these phenotypes are lacking, hampering development of urgently needed innovative therapies. Here, we show that Twist1+/− mice with craniosynostosis have increased intracranial pressure and neurocognitive behavioral abnormalities, recapitulating features of human Saethre-Chotzen syndrome. Using a biodegradable material combined with MSCs, we successfully regenerated a functional cranial suture that corrects skull deformity, normalizes intracranial pressure, and rescues neurocognitive behavior deficits. The regenerated suture creates a niche into which endogenous MSCs migrated, sustaining calvarial bone homeostasis and repair. MSC-based cranial suture regeneration offers a paradigm shift in treatment to reverse skull and neurocognitive abnormalities in this devastating disease.
